I went back to Taiwan one year ago and live here now. As for Chinese exceptionalism, nowadays only a very small portion of Taiwanese hold that idea. Once you open eyes to the whole world, that ideology naturally disappears. But you have to REALLY open your eyes. It is relatively easy for Taiwanese people, but I don't know how it is for Chinese.
Problems occur when Chinese exceptionalism runs up against US exceptionalism. Regardless who holds it, it's an unfortunate mindset.
If "grabbing" territory far beyond borders means aggressive and indicates exceptionalism, that explains a lot about the US, which has Hawaii and Guam as parts of its territory.

A thoughtful piece from a man well-versed in China studies. He has a unique perspective and insight from, as he said, "having been educated at Maoists universities in (his) 20s." Not many can claim that.

My only quibble--and it is a small one--is that Chinese exceptionalism is not a product of the PRC gov't. It is a long-cherished assumption in Taiwan and Hong Kong as well. As I have heard countless Chinese over the past 30+ years state, "Zhongguo ren hen tebie." (Chinese people are very unique/exceptional.) The anthropologist in me wants to reply, "So is every people group," but that is different, of course. China's sense of exceptionalism is one of the things that makes it's relations with the rest of the world so difficult because it leads to the sense of entitlement and, thus, aggression--as witnessed in the grabbing of territory far beyond it's borders in the South China Sea.

I think you need to re-read the article.  The power companies are doing themselves a far bigger favour than they are offering consumers.  They want to sell expensive power during the day to consumers who must use it then, by getting more flexible customers to take power when demand is low, means they don't have to up-grade the grid.  The holy grail for these utilities is flattening the power consumption curve.

Wind power works during the day and during the night, and the daytime users who can't or won't switch to nighttime use are paying for the wind turbines, in spite of the higher price for daytime power. This deal is simply an attempt to shift demand to better match supply without paying more capital costs for solar (which only generates during the day and thus doesn't have this issue), storage or connection to other grids. Once electric cars (particularly smart ones that will automatically charge themselves only when the price is lowest) become more common (and cheaper) this problem will go away.

This makes electric cars look even more attractive: fuel is free at night, and you don't need to install your own free energy collector (solar, wind, geothermal)

Bill, peak demand alone does not determine a utility's fixed cost.  The load duration curve determines the mix of base load, vs intermediate, vs peaking generation.   Generally, the greater the load duration (flatter the curve) the more base generation there must be in the mix.  And the more base in the mix, the greater the fixed cost.   This was recognized by state utility regulators years ago, when they moved from cost determination techniques that took into account a customer's, or customer class' annual load duration in addition to peak demand responsibility.

The dispatching costs on electric grids can actually result in slightly negative marginal costs of electricity per kwhr when supply is high and demand is low.

But what bothers me is that nothing is actually free. This supply comes with substantial fixed costs, either in the form of demand charges paid to suppliers under contract, or the capital carrying charges on investments owned by the utility. There is something fundamentally wrong with allowing some users to take great economic benefits from the system, while contributing nothing to the fixed cost necessary to provide that "free" energy.

Jeff, absolutely. While I never worked in hospices or hospitals, I often visited them, and the conditions in which people died were very often gravely disquieting. If I may suggest a book about hospice care which brings out the hazards of dying peacefully in such places, I would suggest that people read Julia Lawton's anthropological study of an English hospice entitled "The Dying Process: Patients' Experiences of Palliative Care," published in 2000 by Routledge.

The author envies the children whose parents died in hospice or hospital care. She should not do so. For over forty years I've worked in just these settings. They are not good places to die, not for the dying or their children. While it is true that families are relieved of the dirty work, consider what they lose: a last and probably best chance to connect intimately with those who gave them life, and the chance to come to a profound understanding of their own mortality.
It is not easy to put your childishness behind when a sick parent calls out from a place of fear and pain. But, it needs to be done. Failure to engage in this transaction will lead to far greater pain than otherwise.

The medical practices have issues, but let's remember a LOT of very elderly folks (I mean here, over 85 and often with cognitive issues) live in retirement homes, Assisted Living and nursing homes. Those places have THEIR OWN financial incentives. They CHARGE for what they call "medical management". My aunt lived in such place, and they charged $700 a month if you required even a daily multi-vitamin -- residents were FORBIDDEN to take even a vitamin themselves, or from family. That meant either no meds of any kind OR you had to pay $700 a month. If you took more than 5 meds, or required anything like a diabetic diet, it was more like $1500 extra a month. This is on top of about $4000 for the basic facility fee.

Frankly, it is a racket. From what I saw, there was NOTHING provided in terms of health care or maintenance, entertainment, room & board, that would justify a cost of $5000 or so a month, yet this is on the low end of what AL care costs and nursing homes are double that. These are private, for-profit businesses and run with virtually no state oversight or rules (at least, ones the facility cannot easily get around).

Many elderly people at least having Medicare insurance, and many also having Medi-gap policies on top of it. Combined with our fee-for-service approach to medicine, this guarantees that they will have too much health-care of the wrong kind provided for them by greedy medical practices, hospitals, and the doctors who head them up. Unless we change this system of medicine, which is unlikely, we will have over-treatment of the elderly.

A friend has Parkinson's. He takes a host of medications, but can barely keep awake.  His type of Parkinson's is such that he has muscle stiffness, as opposed to tremors.  Of course he takes a statin.  Statins increase muscle discomfort.  His mouth is always dry from  his meds.  His teeth and gums have suffered from dry mouth.  He takes other meds for various reasons.  The upshot is that he's rarely totally awake.  So, though none of these meds will slow the progression of the disease, merely mask the symptoms, I think he would be better off attacking the problem with exercise and various supplements.  I've advised COQ10, also advised by some neurologists, but he has resisted that, telling me his physician doesn't think it would help.  I don't think what his physician is doing helps.  Another friend's father had Parkinson's and was also rarely awake.  She and her brother have decided not to take any meds and are prepping themselves for the possibility of the disease by doing lots of exercise, taking supplements,  and trying to maintain a sensible diet.  I think their plan has merit.
